content:
It 'sounds like' you installed Thunderbird from Microsoft, not the official site at thunderbird.net, in which case your profile is probably at AppData\Local\Packages\MozillaThunderbird If so, my personal recommendation is this:

- locate the profile, preferably a thunderbird\profiles<profilename> structure similar to regular thunderbird - copy to safe location while thunderbird is NOT running - uninstall thunderbird and then download and install from thunderbird.net - copy the saved thunderbird folder to the place you are already aware of as default - restart thunderbird

I omitted little details on exact file placement as you seem familiar with that. There is nothing wrong with the Microsoft version, but if you ever need to do troubleshooting, that feature doesn't work. NOTE: when going to thunderbird.net, the default is the monthly version. if you want the ESR version, you must select it from the options.
creator: davidsk

content: I solved the problem by deleting a second account in Thunderbird. Appearantly that account disrupted my main account

content: If your folders consist of just inbox, sent, draft, trash, a switch from IMAP to POP will put future messages on PC and no further action would be needed, other than copying existing sent folder to PC. If you want to just transfer some messages to PC, you could highlight and copy selected messages to a Local Folders folder, and then delete those highlighted messages from the server.
creator: davidsk

content: thanks david but how do I change my imap setting to pop to achieve the desired goal of removing the emails to my gmails server to my computer. thus reducing my storage needs. tia
creator: smelm0

content: First, create a POP account along side of the IMAP account. This will automatically download all messages in inbox to PC and delete from server. Second, install the importexport NG addon if not already done Third, highlight the IMAP sent folder, rightclick, select the importexport option to export as EML to a local Windows folder Now, Highlight the POP sent folder, rightclick and select importexport option to import EML messages and select that Windows folder If you now have everything for account now on PC, you can safely remove the IMAP account. When prompted to remove data, click yes.
creator: davidsk

Quotation from the above link:

As a matter of fact: when I "uncheck" the option "Include messages in this folder in Global search results" the item "Open Message in Conversation" disappears from the context menu.

content: If I understand correctly, you have two thunderbird setups on the same PC and want both to access a common account, but not simultaneously. Here's a way to do that: - click account setting pane and then the desired account. click server settings pane and note the Local Directory entry (bottom line) on the pane. This is where the account is stored. write that down. - now, on the other PC, click to same pane for that same account and overtype the Local Directory entry to match the one on the other PC. Thunderbird will likely close and restart. - you should now have access to the one account from both thunderbird setups, one at a time.
creator: davidsk
